sect1.title: Bitwise Logical Operations
sect1.para: In addition to the &R5RS; set of procedures that deal with numbers, &SISC; provides operators for performing bitwise logic operations on a limited range of integers. The domain of the logical operators are exact real integers of the range -2,147,483,648 to 2,147,483,647 inclusive. An error is raised if the logical operators are applied to integers outside this range, to a non-integer, or a non-real.

blockquote.para:
&procedure;
integer logand integer
integer
Performs the logical AND of all the provided arguments.

&procedure;
integer logor integer
integer
Performs the logical OR of all the provided arguments.

&procedure;
integer logxor integer
integer
Performs the logical exclusive-OR of all the provided arguments.

sect1.para: In addition, two operators are provided to perform arithmetic shifts on any integer (these operators do not have the range limitation the previous logical functions do). The shift operators return a newly generated number formed by shifting the provided number left or right by the given number of bits.

Mathematically, if r is the number, and s is the number of bits, ashl calculates:
r x 2s
while ashr calculates
r / 2s
in the integer domain. Both ashl and ashr operate on exact integers and produce only exact integers.

sect1.title: Hash Tables
sect1.para: Hash tables store mappings of keys to values. Hence they are similar to association lists, except that hash tables allow retrieval, addition and modification in constant time whereas association lists typically perform these operations in linear time based on the number of elements.

&SISC; hash tables use eqv? for element comparison, which implies that keys generally ought to be of a type for which comparison with eqv? is meaningful. Furthermore, keys must be immutable. Specifically this excludes dynamically allocated strings, lists and vectors.
&SISC; hash tables are thread-safe, i.e. multiple threads can concurrently access and modify the same hash table.

sect2.title: Creation
sect2.para: Hash tables are a distinct data type. They can be created empty or filled with the contents of an association list. The converse, creating an association list from a hash table, is also supported.

blockquote.para:
&procedure;
hashtable make-hashtable
hashtable
Creates a hash table. When called without an argument, the new hash table is empty, otherwise it is initialized with the elements of hashtable.

sect2.title: Access
sect2.para: All hash table access operations follow a similar pattern. They return the value that was associated with the the given key at the time the operation was invoked. If no binding for the key existed, an optionally supplied value is returned that defaults to #f. This allows the programmer to associate keys with #f values and distinguish this case from not having any association for a key.

blockquote.para:
&procedure;
value hashtable/put! hashtable key val
nobinding
Associates key with val in hashtable. Returns the previous association of key or nobinding, which defaults to #f, if key has no previous association.

&procedure;
value hashtable/get hashtable key
nobinding
Returns the value associated with key in hashtable, or nobinding, which defaults to #f, if key has no association.

&procedure;
value hashtable/remove! hashtable key val
nobinding
Removes the association of key in hashtable. Returns the associated value of key or nobinding, which defaults to #f, if key has no association.

sect2.para: Hash tables can be invoked as procedures. This provides convenient short-cuts for the very common hashtable/get and hashtable/put! operations:

blockquote.para:
&procedure;
value
hashtable key
val
If val is present, then this is equivalent to calling (hashtable/put! hashtable key value), otherwise (hashtable/get hashtable key).

sect2.title: Bulk Operations
sect2.para: Bulk operations are operations that apply to all elements of a hash table.

sect1.title: Procedure Properties
sect1.para: &SISC; allows key/value bindings to be associated with procedures. This has a number of applications. For instance, generic procedures store their methods in a procedure property.
Keys must be symbols. Values are any valid Scheme value. All operations are thread-safe.

blockquote.para:
&procedure;
value procedure-property proc symbol
nobinding
Returns the value associated with the property symbol of procedure proc, or nobinding, which defaults to #f, if the property is not set.

&procedure;
value set-procedure-property! proc symbol val
nobinding
Sets the property symbol of procedure proc to the value val. Returns the previous value of the property or nobinding, which defaults to #f, if the property was unset.

&procedure;
value procedure-property! proc symbol thunk
nobinding
Returns the value associated with the property symbol of procedure proc. If the property is unset then thunk is evaluated and the property is set to the result, which is also returned. The nobinding argument, which defaults to #f, denotes the value indicating that the property is unset.

sect1.title: Third-Party Libraries
sect1.para: &SISC; provides hooks for accessing a number of third-party Scheme libraries.

note.para: This functionality has not undergone much testing.

sect2.title: SRFIs
sect2.para: The Scheme Requests For Implementation (SRFI) process aims to coordinate libraries and other additions to the Scheme language between different Scheme implementations. For details see which describes the process and contains a list of all available SRFIs.

sect3.title: SRFI Modules
sect3.para:
In &SISC; each SRFI is encapsulated in a module. See for details of &SISC;'s module system. The definitions for SRFI modules are not included in the standard &SISC; heap build and hence must be loaded separately from the srfi.scm, which can be found in the scheme-src directory of the &SISC; distribution:
(load "path/srfi.scm")
Loading this takes quite a while, which is one reason why the module definitions are not included in the standard heap build.

sect3.title: Using SRFIs
sect3.para:
&SISC; currently supports SRFIs 0,1,2,5,6,7,8,9,11,12,13,14,16,23,24. Once the SRFI module definitions have been loaded as described above, an SRFI n can be imported using
(import srfi-n)
e.g.
(import srfi-1) (xcons 1 2) ;=> (2 . 1)

SRFI modules, like all modules in &SISC;, can be imported/used by other modules. Doing so does not pollute the top-level environment with the definitions exported by the module, i.e. any code outside the importing module remains unaffected.

sect2.title: SLIB
sect2.para: The SLIB portable scheme library provides compatibility and utility functions for standard Scheme implementations. It is supported by many Schemes, including &SISC;.

sect3.title: Downloading and Installation
sect3.para: The latest version of SLIB is available from as both a zip file and RPM. The site also hosts an online version of the SLIB manual.

Download SLIB and install it in a convenient location. The RPM will by default be installed in /usr/share/slib/. Do not worry when you see some errors about missing programs such as mzscheme and scheme48 when installing the RPM - these happen because SLIB tries to auto-configure itself for various Schemes that you may not have installed on your system.

sect3.title: Environment
sect3.para:
Using SLIB in &SISC; requires two Java system properties to be set:
sisc.home
This should (but does not actually have to) point to the location where you have installed &SISC;. If you are using one of the scripts from the binary &SISC; distribution in order to run &SISC; then this property will automatically be set to the value of the SISC_HOME environment variable.
SCHEME_LIBRARY_PATH
This must point to the location where you installed SLIB. Other Schemes supporting SLIB tend to use an environment variable SCHEME_LIBRARY_PATH, so it is advisable to define that (if it is not already defined) and run Java with a -Dslib.path=... option based on the environment variable. If you are using the scripts from the binary $SISC; distribution in order to run &SISC; then you can set the property by adding the -Dslib.path=... to the JAVAOPT environment variable.
You need to ensure that all potential users of SLIB have read permissions to files in the directories referred to by the above system properties.
You also need access to the file slib.scm, which can be found in the scheme-src directory of the &SISC; distribution.

sect3.title: Building the Catalog
sect3.para: Make sure that the above system properties are set and that you have write permissions to the sisc.home directory; often this means you need to be logged in as a privileged user.

Start &SISC; as you normally would. At the prompt type
(load "path/slib.scm") (require 'new-catalog) (exit)
where path is the directory containing the slib.scm file.
The above should create a file slibcat in the sisc.home directory. It is a good idea to check that this has indeed happened.

sect3.title: Using SLIB
sect3.para:
Make sure the above system properties are set. Start &SISC; as you normally would. At the prompt load slib.scm as described above, i.e.
(load "path/slib.scm")
You can now load SLIB modules using require, e.g.
(require 'tsort) (tsort '((shirt tie belt) (tie jacket) (belt jacket) (watch) (pants shoes belt) (undershorts pants shoes) (socks shoes)) eq?)
loads the topological sorting module and invokes one of the procedures defined by it.

Please refer to the SLIB manual for further details of what modules are available. Note however that, as with most other Schemes supported by SLIB, there will be some modules that are not available or do not work in &SISC;.
